item.title: Germany Backs Trump’s NATO Goal of 5% Defense Spending
item.description: German Foreign Minister Johann Wadephul said his country is prepared to move toward spending 5% of its economic output on defense, backing a goal pushed by US President Donald Trump for NATO members and underscoring the new Berlin government’s more aggressive stance on the military.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Palasciano, Arne Delfs, Michael Nienaber

media:content.media:description: German Air Force Eurofighter aircraft during a NATO air force exercise dubbed "Ramstein Flag" at Leeuwarden Air Base, in April.

item.title: Meloni Wants Another Cut to Italy’s Payroll Taxes in Next Budget
item.description: Italian Premier Giorgia Meloni’s government wants to ease the burden on middle-class earnings with another giveaway in the coming year, according to the economics chief of her political party.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Migliaccio, Donato Paolo Mancini

media:content.media:description: Giorgia Meloni

item.title: JD Vance Plans Return to Vatican for Pope Leo’s Inaugural Mass
item.description: Vice President JD Vance will attend the inaugural mass of Pope Leo XIV following the pontiff’s historic election as the first American leader of the Roman Catholic Church.
item.dc:creator: Kate Sullivan, Akayla Gardner, Skylar Woodhouse

media:content.media:description: JD Vance at Good Friday mass in St. Peter's Basilica at the Vatican on April 18.

item.title: Senators Seek Records on Trump-Linked Firm’s Stablecoin Venture
item.description: Senators Elizabeth Warren and Jeff Merkley are asking World Liberty Financial Inc., the Trump family’s crypto project, to preserve records of communications with the Trump administration and to provide copies of communications regarding its new stablecoin, USD1.
item.dc:creator: Steven T. Dennis

media:content.media:description: Senator Elizabeth Warren. Photographer: Jemal Countess/Getty Images

item.title: Turkey’s Erdoğan Emerges as Trump’s Peacemaker Proxy
item.description: Welcome to Balance of Power, bringing you the latest in global politics. If you haven’t yet, sign up here.
item.dc:creator: Beril Akman

item.title: How Close Is Iran to a Nuclear Weapon as Trump Eyes a Deal?
item.description: Iran has faced suspicion for decades over its nuclear ambitions and whether it’s developing the capability to fire an atomic weapon.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Tirone

media:content.media:description: The reactor building at the Bushehr nuclear power plant in southern Iran. Photographer: Majid Asgaripour/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Russia Sends Jet as Estonia Tries to Inspect Shadowy Oil Tanker
item.description: Russia deployed a fighter jet in NATO airspace this week after Estonia tried to inspect a so-called shadow fleet tanker passing the EU-member’s economic area, Estonia’s Foreign Minister Margus Tsahkna said.
item.dc:creator: Ott Tammik

media:content.media:description: A Russian Sukhoi Su-57 fifth-generation fighter aircraft. Photographer: Idrees Mohammed/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Macron Says EU Must Reinvent Its Relationship With the UK
item.description: The European Union must revamp its alliance with the UK, French President Emmanuel Macron said Thursday in Paris, ahead of a summit next week that aims to reset relations between the bloc and its former member country.
item.dc:creator: Samy Adghirni, James Regan

media:content.media:description: Emmanuel Macron, France's president, at the Elysee Palace in Paris, France, on Wednesday, May 7, 2025. Friedrich Merz travels to Paris and Warsaw on Wednesday on his first foreign trip as German chancellor, still reeling from a humiliating setback in Tuesday’s government transition that raised early questions about his leadership. Photographer: Nathan Laine/Bloomberg

item.title: China Accuses US of ‘Unilateral Bullying’ on Huawei AI Chips
item.description: Beijing has pushed back against a US decision aimed at curbing Chinese-made artificial intelligence chips, a first sign of discord between the world’s two largest economies since they agreed to a trade truce last weekend.
item.dc:creator: Philip Glamann, Jing Li

media:content.media:description: FUZHOU, CHINA - AUGUST 19: A Huawei Ascend AI chip is on display during a Huawei Data Infrastructure Summit at Fuzhou Digital China Convention and Exhibition Center on August 19, 2020 in Fuzhou, Fujian Province of China. (Photo by Zhang Bin/China News Service via Getty Images)

item.title: EU Trade Officials See Signs of Optimism for US Tariff Deal
item.description: Top trade officials from the European Union’s member states expressed increased confidence that they can reach an agreement to dial back the US’s tariff hikes after the Trump administration struck a tentative deal with the UK and agreed to significantly de-escalate its conflict with China.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valero

media:content.media:description: EU Commissioner for Trade and Economic Security, Maros Sefcovic arrives at the Europa building in Brussels, on May 15.

item.title: RFK Jr.'s Quest to Make Americans Eat Healthier Will Be Costly
item.description: Ultra-processed foods have made US diets among the least expensive — and the most unhealthy — in the world. The health secretary wants to change that.
item.dc:creator: Ilena Peng, Deena Shanker, Agnieszka de Sousa

item.title: Bolsonaro Ally Woos Wall Street, Building Presidential Buzz
item.description: This week at a luncheon in New York filled with CEOs and investors representing a big portion of Brazil’s economy, Sao Paulo Governor Tarcisio de Freitas looked and acted like someone seeking higher office.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Gamarski, Fernando Travaglini

media:content.media:description: Tarcsio de Freitas

item.title: Trump Says US and Iran Are Closer to Reaching a Nuclear Deal
item.description: President Donald Trump said the US might be getting closer to an agreement with Iran to curb the Islamic Republic’s nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Sykes

media:content.media:description: (Photo by IIPA via Getty Images) Photographer: Handout/Getty Images Europe

item.title: Europe Slams Putin on Ukraine Talks as Trump Dangles Turkey Trip
item.description: Top European diplomats accused Russian President Vladimir Putin of undermining talks with Ukraine aimed at securing a halt to his war, though the US struck a more cautious tone ahead of a potential meeting in Turkey.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Drozdiak, Andrea Palasciano, Selcan Hacaoglu

media:content.media:description: Vladimir Medinsky Photographer: Getty Images/Getty Images

item.title: Trade Chiefs Jostle for Time With Greer at APEC Meeting in Korea
item.description: Trade chiefs from some of the world’s biggest economies are competing for access to US Trade Representative Jamieson Greer as they seek to advance negotiations with Washington at a gathering in South Korea.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara, Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: Jamieson Greer Photographer: Kayla Bartkowski/Getty Images

item.title: Trump Says India Offered to Remove All Tariffs on US Goods
item.description: President Donald Trump said India has made an offer to drop tariffs on US goods, as the Asian nation negotiates a deal to avert higher import taxes.
item.dc:creator: Jordan Fabian, Shruti Srivastava

media:content.media:description: President Donald Trump attends a meeting with business leaders in Doha on May 15. Photographer: Brendan Smialowski/Getty Images

item.title: Banned Candidate Backs Romania’s Far-Right Presidential Hopeful
item.description: Romania’s former presidential frontrunner Calin Georgescu has endorsed far-right candidate George Simion in a last-minute push to sway voters just days before Sunday’s close run-off vote.
item.dc:creator: Irina Vilcu

media:content.media:description: Calin Georgescu, center right, walks next to George Simion, center left, in Mogosoaia, Romania, on May 4.

item.title: South African President to Meet Trump in Bid to Mend Ties
item.description: South African President Cyril Ramaphosa plans to hold talks with his US counterpart Donald Trump in Washington on May 21 and hopes to ease a simmering diplomatic row between the two nations.
item.dc:creator: S'thembile Cele

media:content.media:description: Cyril Ramaphosa, South Africa's president, during a news conference following a meeting with Volodymyr Zelenskiy, Ukraine's president, at the Union Buildings in Pretoria, South Africa, on Thursday, April 24, 2025. President Volodymyr Zelenskiy became the fist leader of Ukraine to visit South Africa in a bid to expand diplomatic outreach while he can no longer fully rely on US as his nation’s key ally and the peace deal with Russia remains elusive.

item.title: US Approves $304 Million Missile Sale to Turkey as Ties Warm Up
item.description: The US approved the sale of $304 million-worth of missiles to Turkey as the NATO allies work to strengthen trade and defense ties.
item.dc:creator: Selcan Hacaoglu

media:content.media:description: An AIM-120 AMRAAM missile.

item.title: US Treasuries, Re-Imported Japanese Cars Seen as Trade Leverage
item.description: Holding longer-term Treasuries and importing Japanese cars manufactured in the US are among the possible bargaining chips for Tokyo in its talks with Washington over President Donald Trump’s sweeping tariffs, according to the leader of a small but influential opposition party.
item.dc:creator: Akemi Terukina, Sakura Murakami

media:content.media:description: Traffic travels along a road as pedestrians using umbrellas walk along sidewalks in Tokyo, Japan, on Wednesday, April 1, 2020. Japan’s coronavirus numbers have been ticking up, sparking alarm that it could be the next major country to see an explosive jump in infections. It’s also raising questions about whether Tokyo is about to go into a European-style lockdown -- speculation the government is trying to squash. Photographer: Noriko Hayashi/Bloomberg

item.title: UniCredit Sends Letter to Berlin Saying It’s Open to Talks
item.description: UniCredit SpA has sent congratulatory letters to the new German government that also signaled its willingness to hold talks, according to people familiar with the matter, indicating the Italian bank is seeing a potential opening to improve fraught relations.
item.dc:creator: Kamil Kowalcze, Sonia Sirletti

media:content.media:description: Andrea Orcel

item.title: Zimbabweans Escaping Economic Woes in a Bind as UK Scraps Care Visas
item.description: Zimbabwean workers looking to migrate to the UK by obtaining care work are in a bind after Prime Minister Keir Starmer’s administration announced plans to permanently scrap visas for that category of employees.
item.dc:creator: Ray Ndlovu, Lucy White

media:content.media:description: Informal street traders sell goods from stalls along a road in the central business district of Harare, Zimbabwe, on Monday, Feb. 12, 2024. Zimbabwe may back its currency with gold in an effort to end exchange-rate instability, Finance Minister Mthuli Ncube said. Photographer: Cynthia R Matonhodze/Bloomberg

item.title: Putin Criticizes MH17 Probe in Meeting With Malaysia’s Anwar
item.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin criticized a United Nations probe that found his country culpable for the downing of Malaysia Airlines flight MH17, which killed all 298 passengers and crew in 2014.
item.dc:creator: Joy Lee

media:content.media:description: The wreckage of flight MH17 two days after it crashed in east Ukraine, in July 2014. Photographer: Dominique Faget/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Serbia’s Embattled Leader Looks to Leverage Trump Family Ties
item.description: President Aleksandar Vucic wants to reap the rewards of cultivating links with the MAGA movement.
item.dc:creator: Alan Crawford, Misha Savic

media:content.media:description: Aleksandar Vucic, Serbia's president, during an interview in his office in Belgrade, Serbia, on Friday, Jan. 10, 2025. Vucic called a US decision to sanction Naftna Industrija Srbije, the country’s sole refiner that’s controlled by Gazprom, very harsh and said “some kind of transaction” will be needed to ensure its functioning.

item.title: Could This Tax Overhaul Spark a UK Wealth Exodus?
item.description: A new study warns elimination of “nom-dom” status might just cost the government more money than it brings in. Or is the fear overblown?
item.dc:creator: Tala Ahmadi, Sommer Saadi

media:content.media:description: Bundles of new British 20-pound banknotes in London. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

item.title: Why Poland’s Election Is a Barometer for Europe’s Populist Wave
item.description: Poland’s presidential election will determine whether the country can restore the rule of law and remain a reliable partner in the European Union after nearly a decade of divisive right-wing populist rule.
item.dc:creator: Piotr Skolimowski, Wojciech Moskwa

media:content.media:description: Supporters of Rafal Trzaskowski at an election rally in the Main Square in Krakow, Poland, on May 13, 2025. Photographer: Jakub Porzycki/Anadolu/Getty Images

item.title: US-China Trade Clash Risks Making Europe Dumping Ground for Cheap Goods
item.description: China’s widening trade surplus with the European Union is fueling fresh concerns that the 27-nation bloc risks becoming a dumping ground for cheap goods in the volatile tariff confrontation between Washington and Beijing.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger, William Horobin

media:content.media:description: Shipping containers at the Port of Barcelona.

item.title: China Pauses Dual-Use Export Curbs Targeting US Firms
item.description: China has suspended a ban on exports of items with both military and civil applications — likely including some rare earths — to 28 US companies as part of the trade detente struck between the world’s two largest economies.
item.dc:creator: Li Liu

item.title: US Says It Lacks Power to Return Migrants in El Salvador Prison
item.description: The Trump administration urged a federal judge not to pursue the return of alleged Venezuelan gang members who were deported to a notorious prison in El Salvador, saying the US lacks authority to get the men released.
item.dc:creator: Robert Burnson

media:content.media:description: Photo by Alex Brandon-Pool/Getty Images)

item.title: China’s Investors Signal Trade Truce Is No Panacea for Markets
item.description: The trade truce is not enough to ignite a rush into Chinese financial assets amid expectations of reduced policy stimulus and lingering uncertainty on a final deal.
item.dc:creator: John Cheng, Iris Ouyang
